Minute Entry for proceedings held with chambers of Magistrate Judge Bernard G. Skomal: Plaintiff's counsel contacted Judge Skomal's chambers regarding the filing of a motion for expedited discovery on January 14, 2021. Before any briefing may be filed, the parties must meet and confer. If the parties can agree on a proposal, they may file a joint motion with their proposal. If they do not agree after meeting and conferring, they may file a joint statement setting forth each parties' position on the issue. The parties must meet and confer by January 27, 2021 and file either a joint motion or a joint statement by February 8, 2021. It must include the parties' proposed date to file their Rule 26(f) report and proposed deadlines for completion of fact and expert discovery. Additionally, if either party seeks discovery related to any particular topics on an expedited basis the scope of that discovery should be specifically identified. If a joint statement is filed, it is limited to five pages each with any exhibits summarized or quoted within the briefing. Because joint statements must include not only each parties' position, but a parties' response to the opposing party, the parties must exchange their briefing in advance of the deadline to submit a joint statement to allow each party to respond to the other's arguments.(no document attached) (rxa) (Entered: 01/15/2021)

case_data.name: E.A.R.R. v. Department of Homeland Security
case_data.plaintiff_description: Migrants with disabilities and health conditions and their family members who have been forcibly removed to Mexico under the Migrant Protection Protocols.
case_data.summary:
On November 2, 2020, asylum seekers with disabilities and health conditions filed this putative class-action suit against the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Customs and Border Protection in the Southern District of California. The suit alleged that defendants violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 by forcibly returning plaintiffs to Mexico under the Migrant Protection Protocols (the “MPP”). Under the MPP, asylum seekers entering the United States from Mexico were returned to Mexico and forced to wait outside of the U.S. for the duration of their immigration proceedings. The plaintiffs stated that MPP conflicted with CBP’s own procedure at the time that asylum seekers with “known physical or mental health issues” could not be sent to Mexico. They alleged that DHS failed to put in place effective methods to ensure that people with known physical or mental health conditions were exempt from MPP and to identify and assess, for accommodations, immigrants with disabilities. The plaintiffs sought an order enjoining the defendants from continuing forcible removal of class members under MPP and requiring the defendants to put in place practices and procedures in compliance with Section 504. They also requested attorneys’ fees. The plaintiffs were represented by the Civil Rights Education and Enforcement Center, Texas Civil Rights Project, and private counsel. The case was assigned to Judge Todd W. Robinson and Magistrate Judge Bernard G. Skomal.

On November 3, 2020, the case was related to Doe v. McAleenan, which similarly challenged deportation under MPP.

On December 22, 2020, the defendants filed a motion to stay pending the appeal of Innovation Law Lab v. Nielson. The judge denied the motion on February 19, 2021. There were joint motions to continue on March 2, 2021.

On December 23, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. They requested that defendants stop subjecting members of the putative class to the MPP. They further requested that defendants put in place mechanisms ensuring execution of CBP’s protocols of exempting those with known physical or mental health issues, that family members of the putative class be excluded pursuant to the Family Unit Policy, and that defendants put in place practices and policies to identify immigrants with disabilities and provide accommodations necessary for those with disabilities to prepare for their asylum proceedings. On the same day, the plaintiffs also filed a motion requesting class certification for asylum seekers with disabilities and their family members.

On February 22, 2021, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction. Before the court had a chance to rule on this motion, however, the parties notified the court that they had reached a settlement in principle. The parties notified the court on June 17 and requested the court to vacate all pending dates and to set a settlement conference. The parties exchanged drafts of the settlement for several weeks, but ongoing uncertainty in the Biden administration's immigration policies, including the MPP, delayed the process. On March 29, 2022, the court dismissed all outstanding motions as moot, including plaintiffs' motions for preliminary judgment and to certify the class as well as defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction. On April 28, the court stayed the proceedings for 90 days.

This case is on-going pending resumption of settlement discussions and the stay's expiration in July of 2022.
case_data.summary_short: On November 2, 2020 asylum seekers with disabilities and health conditions filed a putative class-action suit against the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Customs and Border Protection in the Southern District of California. The plaintiffs alleged that defendant's violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. The Biden Administration's immigration policy shifted during settlement discussions, and the court stayed proceedings until July 2022. This case is on-going.
case_data.summary_tiny: In a suit against @DHSgov challenging "remain in Mexico" brought by @TXCivilRights and its co-counsel, the parties have requested a stay pending changes in US immigration policy.

1  1.  Named Plaintiffs1 are men, women, and children who represent putative 
2  classes of migrants with disabilities and health conditions and their family members 
3  whom  the  Department  of  Homeland  Security  (“DHS”)  and  its  sub-component 
4  Customs and Border Protection (“CBP”) have forcibly returned to Mexico under the 
5  so-called  Migrant  Protection  Protocols  (the  “MPP”).  Defendants’  own  policies 
6  categorically prohibit placing people with “mental or physical health issues in the 
7  MPP.” This is far from accidental. Instead, the brutal practice of ignoring this policy, 
8  refusing disability accommodations, and sending people with disabilities to survive 
9  in makeshift refugee camps and shelters in Mexico is widespread. The risk of harm 
10  to people with disabilities in this program is imminent, substantial, and irreparable. 
11  Countless individuals have tried and failed to overcome the everyday deprivations of 
12  water, sanitation, medicine, and reasonable aids in order to prepare and present their 
13  cases in inaccessible courts without basic accommodations. 
14  2.  Prior  to  being  placed  in  the  MPP,  CBP  takes  a  recently  arrived 
15  immigrant into custody and detains them in a CBP processing center. As a result of 
16  this process, Defendants knew or should have known during Plaintiffs’ time in CBP 
17  custody  that  Plaintiffs  or  their  family  member  had  physical  or  mental  health 
18   
1 A motion to proceed under anonymity is forthcoming. In this case, Plaintiffs assert 
19  multiple  facts  that  support proceeding with  anonymity.  They  (1) face imminent 
threats from anti-immigrant groups in Northern Mexico; (2) disclose information of 
20  the utmost intimacy about the physical abuse and discrimination that could subject 
them to being ostracized; and (3) face potential retaliation from port officials, who 
21  have threatened to label as “terrorists” other migrants who peacefully raised public 
awareness of their plight, an action that would bar that person from receiving asylum. 
22  These factors counsel in favor of proceeding anonymously. Does I thru XXIII v. 
Advanced Textile Corp., 214 F.3d 1058, 1067-68 (9th Cir. 2000) (party may preserve 
23  anonymity  in  judicial  proceedings  when  “special  circumstances  justify”  this 
treatment – i.e., when the plaintiff’s need for anonymity outweighs prejudice to the 
24  [Defendants] and the public’s interest in knowing [Plaintiff’s] identity”); see also Al 
Otro Lado, Inc. v. Nielsen, No. 17-cv-02366-BAS-KSC, 2017 WL 6541446, at *1 
25  (S.D. Cal. Dec. 20, 2017) (granting anonymity to asylum seekers who brought suit 
against the government for denying them access to the U.S. asylum system through 
26  unlawful policies and practices). Moreover, ten of the plaintiffs are minor children 
and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure require redaction of the names of minor 
27  children. Fed. R. Civ. Proc. 5.2(a) (“In an electronic or paper filing with the court 
that contains . . . the name of an individual known to be a minor, . . . the filing may 
28  include only . . . the minor’s initials”). Plaintiffs will disclose their identities to the 
representatives of Defendants.  
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
1 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  conditions, including disabilities. Plaintiffs’ conditions are open and obvious, well 
2  documented, and/or were repeatedly reported to CBP agents. Further, Defendants are 
3  obligated to put in place screening procedures to identify people with disabilities.  
4  3.  Defendants have utterly failed to establish mechanisms to ensure that its 
5  agents follow Defendants’ policies, including exempting migrants with physical or 
6  mental health conditions from the MPP. As a result, Defendants’ employees or agents 
7  subjected Plaintiffs to the MPP, forcing them to return to Mexico pending their 
8  immigration proceedings and any appeals. 
9  4.  As a result of Defendants’ actions, Plaintiffs and putative class members 
10  in Mexico do not have sufficient shelter, are denied essential medical equipment and 
11  care, and/or face barriers such as inaccessible buildings and facilities, a lack of sign 
12  language  interpreters,  and  a  lack  of  effective  communication,  all  of  which 
13  substantially affect their ability to prepare for and adequately aid in their defense in 
14  removal proceedings.  
15  5.  Further,  Defendants  send  Plaintiffs  and  members  of  the  class—
16  sometimes  completely  without  warning—to  areas  in  Mexico  for  which  the 
17  Department of State has given the highest travel warning due to rampant murder, 
18  armed robbery, carjacking, kidnapping, extortion, and sexual assault, and to some 
19  areas where the Department of State warns U.S. citizens that local law enforcement 
20  is not capable of protecting them. This is particularly harmful to Plaintiffs and 
21  members of the putative class, who are especially vulnerable to persecution, torture, 
22  and human trafficking in Mexico.  
23  6.  As a result of these conditions, Plaintiffs and putative class members 
24  cannot meaningfully prepare for or participate in removal proceedings, including 
25  asserting any defenses to removal to another country claims. For example, Plaintiffs 
26  are forced to divert their time, energy, and resources to attempt to obtain—sometimes 
27  unsuccessfully—basic medical equipment and care, making it virtually impossible 
28  for them to meaningfully assert defenses to removal or otherwise prepare for removal 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
2 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  proceedings.  
2  7.  Despite repeated pleas from Plaintiffs and advocates, and despite clear 
3  evidence of harm, Defendants continue to refuse to exempt Plaintiffs and members 
4  of the class from the MPP notwithstanding that their own policies and applicable laws 
5  require them to do so.  
6  8.  Plaintiffs  seek  a  declaration  that  Defendants’  actions  violate  the 
7  Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), 5 U.S.C. § 701 et seq., and Section 504 of 
8  the  Rehabilitation  Act  of  1973,  29  U.S.C.  § 794,  and  seek  an  order  enjoining 
9  Defendants from continuing to subject Plaintiffs and putative class members to the 
10  MPP, and requiring Defendants to put in place practices and procedures to satisfy 
11  their obligations under Section 504. 
12  I.  PARTIES 
13  A.  The Plaintiffs

1  children to remain in Mexico under the MPP.

1  20.  Plaintiff  G.F.F.  is  a  thirty-eight-year-old  man,  and  is  a  qualified 
2  individual with a disability. He has depression and insomnia. Since around July 2019, 
3  Defendants have forced him to remain in Mexico under the MPP.

19  with a disability. Doctors diagnosed her with lissencephaly, a disorder characterized

21  have forced her and her mother, K.A.M., to remain in Mexico under the MPP.

25  family to remain in Mexico under the MPP. 
26  26.  Plaintiff N.R.R. is a forty-four-year-old woman and the wife of a person 
27  with disabilities (D.G.M.). Since on or about July 28, 2019, Defendants have forced 
28  her and her family to remain in Mexico under the MPP. 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
5 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  27.  Plaintiff H.H.M. is a twenty-year-old man and is a qualified individual 
2  with a disability. He is deaf and does not communicate through any standardized sign 
3  language. He relies on his sister, E.H.M., almost exclusively for communication. 
4  Since on or about March 21, 2020, Defendants have forced him and his family to 
5  remain in Mexico under the MPP. 
6  28.  Plaintiff E.H.M. is a twenty-two-year-old woman and is the sister of 
7  person with disabilities (H.H.M.). Since on or about March 21, 2020, Defendants 
8  have forced her, her child, and her brother to remain in Mexico under the MPP. 
9  29.  Plaintiff  C.J.V.C.  is  a  fourteen-year-old  child  and  is  a  qualified 
10  individual with a disability. He has an amputated leg. Since on or about September 
11  24, 2019, Defendants have forced him and his mother, M.C., to remain in Mexico 
12  under the MPP. 
13  30.  Plaintiff La.V.S.O. is a one-year-old baby and is a qualified individual 
14  with a disability. She was born with congenital hydrocephalus, which causes a 
15  buildup of fluid around her brain and spinal cord and requires specialized medical 
16  treatment. Since on or about February 27, 2020, Defendants have forced her and her 
17  family, including her mother A.A.F.S.O., to remain in Mexico under the MPP. 
18  31.  Al Otro Lado is a non-profit, binational legal services organization 
19  incorporated  in  California.  Al  Otro  Lado  serves  indigent  deportees,  migrants, 
20  refugees and their families, principally in Los Angeles, California and Tijuana, 
21  Mexico. In both locations, the populations that Al Otro Lado serves includes many 
22  individuals with disabilities or who are seriously ill, as well as their families. The 
23  volume of individuals with disabilities or medical conditions subjected to the MPP 
24  requiring Al Otro Lado’s assistance has forced Al Otro Lado to expend significant 
25  additional  time  and  effort,  affecting  the  organization’s  activities  and  staffing, 
26  frustrating its mission, and requiring it to divert its resources.  
27  B.  The Defendants 
28  32.  Defendant  U.S.  Department  of  Homeland  Security  (“DHS”)  is  a 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
6 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  Department within the Executive Branch tasked with enforcing the immigration laws 
2  of the United States. 
3  33.  Defendant Chad Wolf is or was the purported Acting Secretary of DHS 
4  at all times relevant to this suit and is sued in his official capacity. Defendant Wolf 
5  is  responsible  for  the  administration,  implementation,  and  enforcement  of  U.S. 
6  immigration laws and policies pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1103(a), including policies 
7  related to the forcible return of asylum-seekers to Mexico at the U.S. southern border. 
8  34.  Defendant U.S. Customs and Border Protection (“CBP”) is the sub-
9  agency of DHS that is responsible for enforcement operations along the borders of 
10  the United States, including the U.S. southern border. 
11  35.  Defendant Mark A. Morgan is the Acting Commissioner of CBP and is 
12  sued in his official capacity. Defendant Morgan oversees the apprehension and 
13  detention of individuals, including asylum seekers, who enter the United States at or 
14  near the U.S. border. 
15  II.  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
16  36.  This case arises under the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), 5 
17  U.S.C. § 701 et seq., and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. 
18  § 794. 
19  37.  The Court has jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1343, 1346, 
20  2201-2202; 29 U.S.C. § 794a; and 5 U.S.C. § 702. 
21  38.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e) because a substantial part of 
22  the acts or omissions occurred in the Southern District of California.  
23  III.  LEGAL FRAMEWORK 
24  A.  Section 240 Proceedings  
25  39.  The Immigration and Naturalization Act (“INA”) provides different 
26  proceedings for different categories of individuals to determine their admissibility to 
27  the United States. 
28  40.  The proceedings relevant to this case are set forth in section 240 of the 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
7 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  INA, as well as any appeals as of right therefrom including petitions for review, 
2  collectively referred to herein as “Section 240 proceedings.” Section 240 is codified 
3  at 8 U.S.C. § 1229a. Appeals as of right from those proceedings are discussed in 8 
4  C.F.R. § 1003.1. Petitions for review to Circuit Court of Appeals (included in the 
5  term “appeals as of right” for the purposes of this complaint) are discussed in 8 U.S.C. 
6  § 1252. 
7  41.   Section 240 proceedings are evidentiary hearings presided over by an 
8  immigration judge. 
9  42.  Through this, individuals, who are respondents in these proceedings, are 
10  given the opportunity to examine evidence brought against them, to present evidence, 
11  and to cross-examine witnesses. 8 U.S.C. § 1229a(b)(4). 
12  43.  The  respondent  has  the  burden  of  proof  on  most  issues,  and  in 
13  determining whether that burden has been met, an immigration judge focuses on 
14  whether the respondent has submitted credible, persuasive, specific facts. 8 U.S.C. § 
15  1229a(c)(2). Any evidence submitted by the noncitizen must comply with applicable 
16  requirements. 8 U.S.C. § 1229a(c)(3). 
17  44.  A  respondent  who  does  not  appear  for  a  scheduled  Section  240 
18  proceeding  faces  a  significant  risk  that  the  immigration  judge  will  order  their 
19  removal. 8 U.S.C. § 1229a(b)(5). 
20  45.  Appeals as of right, which include appeals to the Board of Immigration 
21  Appeals and petitions for review for the purposes of this complaint as indicated 
22  above, involve review of the factual and legal findings of the agency through briefs, 
23  occasionally including oral argument. A respondent who does not file briefs on 
24  appeal faces a significant risk of having an appeal as of right dismissed. 
25  B.   The Migrant Protection Protocols 
26  46.  The MPP, introduced in December 2018, is a policy of the Trump 
27  administration that purports to grant CBP officers the authority to return to Mexico 
28  people  seeking  admission  to  the  United  States,  pending  their  Section  240 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
8 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  proceedings.2 
2  47.  As of March 2020, Defendants had forcibly returned more than 60,000 
3  people to Mexico pursuant to the MPP. Approximately 25,000 of these individuals 
4  live in makeshift camps and shelters in Mexican border towns.  
5  48.  Individuals placed in the MPP are in Section 240 proceedings. The 
6  process of pursuing Section 240 proceedings under the MPP is itself a grueling 
7  exercise. Immigration court respondents who are set for morning proceedings must 
8  travel through extremely dangerous, sometimes cartel-controlled areas, to present 
9  themselves to CBP agents at the Port of Entry before sunrise. Those set for the 
10  afternoon docket often are not released back into Mexico until late in the evening, 
11  often  after  sunset.  Section  240  proceedings  usually  entail  a  series  of  court 
12  appearances, culminating in a final merits hearing. As a result, prior to receiving an 
13  immigration judge’s determination on the merits of their cases, Plaintiffs and others 
14  in the MPP must often present themselves for court many times. 
15  49.  Respondents in MPP proceedings must first pass a medical inspection 
16  before being permitted to enter immigration court. Some individuals have been 
17  turned away and rescheduled because, for example, abysmal living conditions have 
18  caused them to have lice. After their belongings are inspected, individuals often wait 
19  hours in holding areas before being called for their proceedings.  
20  50.  At San Diego and El Paso, MPP court proceedings are held in the San 
21  Diego and El Paso immigration courts in person, where asylum-seekers interact with 
22  court staff or officials and, when possible, submit documents in person. Once an 
23  asylum seeker is permitted to enter the court, that person is prohibited from exercising 
24  any freedom of movement.  
25  51.  At  Brownsville  and  Laredo,  Texas,  MPP  court  proceedings  are 
26 
 
2 Plaintiffs, including members of the putative class, who entered the United States 
27 
without inspection and were apprehended by CBP agents thereafter, do not 
concede that the INA permits CBP to return them to a contiguous country 
28 
pending removal proceedings by filing this suit.    
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
9 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  conducted in temporary “tent” facilities erected on federal property near the ports of 
2  entry.  These  facilities  are  not  easily  accessible  for  individuals  with  mobility 
3  disabilities, such as C.V.J.C. Those who attend courts at these facilities do not come 
4  face-to-face with any court staff or officials; instead, asylum-seekers interact with the 
5  immigration judge and government attorneys entirely over televideo. Individuals 
6  who have documents to submit to the court must hand the documents to a security 
7  guard  to  scan.  While  waiting  for  others  to  finish  proceedings  with  the  judge, 
8  immigrants are not given any freedom of movement and must ask for and be granted 
9  permission to use restroom facilities. When appearing for the merits portion of their 
10  immigration proceeding, individuals are placed into a repurposed shipping container 
11  that is barely big enough to hold three people. Interpreters are not physically present 
12  for the interviews. Instead, if interpretation is needed, respondents speak through an 
13  interpreter over the phone. 
14  52.  After  proceedings  are  concluded,  depending  on  several  factors, 
15  including whether someone has been granted a non-refoulement interview, people 
16  can wait another several hours, incommunicado, before being returned to Mexico. 
17  53.  The heightened risk of abuse or crimes and the conditions that people 
18  with disabilities face in Mexico—including lack of medical care, medical equipment, 
19  accessible housing and buildings, sign language interpreters, and other necessary 
20  supports—are appalling. 
21  54.  As a result, people with disabilities that Defendants force to return to 
22  Mexico  often  must  focus  all  their  efforts  on  simply  surviving.  They  have  no 
23  meaningful opportunity to prepare for their Section 240 proceedings. In fact, people 
24  with disabilities run the risk of not even being able to appear at their 240 proceedings 
25  because of their disabilities.  
26  55.  DHS, apparently recognizing that the MPP should not be applied to 
27  people with disabilities, has expressly excluded people with known physical or 
28  mental health issues from the MPP in its policies (the “Physical/Mental Health 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
10 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  Exclusion”). 
2  56.  Among other places, the Physical/Mental Health Exclusion is set forth 
3  on a DHS webpage entitled “Migrant Protection Protocols,” last published on August 
4  10, 2020. In a section of this webpage entitled “Are there any exclusions to who is 
5  subject to MPP?” DHS explicitly states that people with “[k]nown physical/mental 
6  health issues” are excluded from the MPP.3 
7  57.  On several other occasions—including in a brief to the Ninth Circuit4 
8  and a statement of “Guiding Principles” applicable to the MPP at all ports of entry5—
9  DHS and CBP have made it clear that the MPP should not be applied to people with 
10  known physical or mental health issues. 
11  58.  Notwithstanding DHS and CBP’s stated policy that the MPP should not 
12  apply to people with known physical or mental health issues, CBP continues to apply 
13  the MPP to such people, returning Plaintiffs and numerous other people with physical 
14  or mental health conditions, including people with disabilities, to Mexico. 
15  59.  On  information  and  belief,  DHS  has  not  put  in  place  effective

1  those people as to the need for accommodations in order to meaningfully 
2  participate in Section 240 proceedings;  
3  c.  Whether placing members of the Section 504 class in the MPP, and 
4  returning them to Mexico, violates DHS regulations by affording such 
5  class members an opportunity to participate in or benefit from Section 
6  240 proceedings that is not equal to that afforded to others; 
7  d.  Whether placing members of the Section 504 class in the MPP, and 
8  returning them to Mexico, violates DHS regulations by providing those 
9  class  members  with  a  benefit  or  service  that  is  not  as  effective  in 
10  affording equal opportunity to obtain the same result as that provided to 
11  others;  
12  e.  Whether Defendants violate DHS regulations by utilizing criteria or 
13  methods of administration the purpose or effect of which is to subject 
14  members of the Section 504 class to discrimination, or that defeat or 
15  substantially impair accomplishment of the objectives of Section 240 
16  proceedings;  
17  f.  Whether placing members of the Section 504 class in the MPP and 
18  returning  them  to  Mexico  denies  them  meaningful  participation  in 
19  Section 240 proceedings; and 
20  g.  Whether excluding people with disabilities from the MPP, which would 
21  be  in  keeping  with  Defendants’  Physical/Mental  Health  Exclusion, 
22  constitutes a reasonable accommodation. 
23  235.  There are questions of law and fact common to the members of the 
24  Family Member Class. Such questions include, but are not limited to: 
25  a.  Whether people with an association to a person with a disability, and 
26  who are injured based on discrimination against that person with a 
27  disability, have a claim under the Rehabilitation Act; 
28  b.  Whether family members have been injured based on their association 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
48 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  with members of the Section 504 class; and 
2  c.  If so, what is the appropriate relief. 
3  236.  Defendants are expected to raise common defenses to the claims of each 
4  class, including denying that their actions violate the law. 
5  237.  The claims of the Accardi/Section 504 class representatives are typical 
6  of those of the Accardi Class, as each Accardi/Section 504 class representative, like 
7  each member of the proposed Accardi class, has a known physical or mental health 
8  issue; each Accardi/Section 504 class representative’s claim arises from the same 
9  policies, practices, or courses of conduct as those of the class; and their claims are 
10  based on the same theory of law as the class’s claims. 
11  238.  The claims of the Accardi/Section 504 are typical of those of the Section 
12  504  class, as each Accardi/Section 504  class  representative  has  a disability  for 
13  purposes of the Rehabilitation Act; each Accardi/Section 504 class representative’s 
14  claim arises from the same policies, practices, or courses of conduct as those of the 
15  class; and their claims are based on the same theory of law as the Section 504 class’s 
16  claims. 
17  239.  The claims of the Family Member class representatives are typical of 
18  those of the Family Member class, as each Family Member class representative has 
19  an  association  with  a  person  with  a  disability;  each  Family  Member  class 
20  representative’s claim arises from the same policies, practices, or courses of conduct 
21  as those of the class; and their claims are based on the same theory of law as the 
22  Family Member class’s claims. 
23  240.  The representative Plaintiffs for each putative class are capable of fairly 
24  and adequately protecting the interests of the members of each class because the 
25  representative  Plaintiffs  do  not  have  any  interests  antagonistic  to  the  classes. 
26  Plaintiffs, as well as the members of the classes, seek to enjoin the unlawful acts and 
27  omissions of Defendants. Finally, Plaintiffs are represented by counsel experienced 
28  in civil rights litigation, litigation regarding the rights of detained individuals and 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
49 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  individuals  with  disabilities,  working  with  individuals  placed  in  the  MPP,  and 
2  complex class action litigation. 
3  241.  This action is maintainable as a class action pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 
4  23(b)(2) because Defendants’ policies, practices, actions, and omissions that form 
5  the basis of this Complaint are common to and apply generally to all members of 
6  each putative class, and the injunctive and declaratory relief sought is appropriate 
7  and will apply to all members of the respective class(es). Defendants’ MPP policies 
8  are  centrally  promulgated,  disseminated,  and  enforced.  The  injunctive  and 
9  declaratory  relief  sought  is  appropriate  and  will  apply  to  all  members  of  the 
10  respective class(es). 
11  VI.  CAUSES OF ACTION 
12  COUNT I 
(Violation of the Administrative Procedure Act/Accardi Doctrine on behalf of 
13  the Accardi class) 
14  242.  All of the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though 
15  fully set forth herein. 
16  243.  The APA provides that courts “shall . . . hold unlawful and set aside 
17  agency action” that is “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not 
18  in accordance with law,” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), or “without observance of procedure 
19  required by law,” id. § 706(2)(D). The Accardi doctrine requires that agencies follow 
20  their own regulations, policies, and procedures. See United States ex rel. Accardi v. 
21  Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 (1954). 
22  244.  Defendants’ Physical/Mental Health Exclusion policy exempts people 
23  with known physical or mental health issues from the MPP.  
24  245.  In spite of this, Defendants placed, and continue to place, individuals 
25  with known physical or mental health issues in the MPP.  
26  246.  Defendants placed the Accardi/Section 504 class representatives in the 
27  MPP even though Defendants knew of those representatives' medical issues. For 
28  example, Defendants were aware of D.Y.S. and D.G.M.’s medical issues because 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
50 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  each of these individuals was hospitalized due to these known medical issues while 
2  in Defendants’ custody. Regardless, Defendants placed each individual in the MPP 
3  shortly after their release from the hospital.  
4  247.  Similarly, Defendants were also aware of other Accardi/Section 504 
5  class representatives’ various medical issues because each provided Defendants with 
6  proof of these medical issues. Plaintiffs presented medical records and prescribed 
7  medications, explained their disabilities, and asked for medical attention for their 
8  deteriorating condition while in Defendants’ custody. Defendants’ own medical team 
9  corroborated many of Plaintiffs’ medical issues and required Defendants to allow the 
10  Plaintiffs access to prescribed medications. Despite this, Defendants placed Plaintiffs 
11  in the MPP.  
12  248.  By placing the Accardi/Section 504 class representatives and members 
13  of the Accardi class in the MPP, Defendants have violated their own policy, and thus 
14  run afoul of the Accardi doctrine, by not following their own policy. 
15  249.  As a result, Accardi/Section 504 class representatives and members of 
16  the Accardi class have been injured, and in the absence of judicial relief, this injury 
17  is ongoing and will continue. 
COUNT II 
18  (Violation of the Rehabilitation Act on behalf of the Section 504 class) 
19  250.  All of the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though 
20  fully set forth herein. 
21  251.  Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (“Section 504”) provides that “no 
22  otherwise qualified individual with a disability . . . shall, solely by reason of his or 
23  her disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be 
24  subjected to discrimination under . . . any program or activity conducted by any 
25  Executive agency . . . .” 29 U.S.C. § 794(a). 
26  252.  Section  504  requires  covered  entities  to  provide  reasonable 
27  accommodations to qualified disabled individuals so that they can have meaningful 
28  access to programs and benefits provided by executive agencies.  
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
51 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  253.  DHS has promulgated regulations implementing the requirements of 
2  Section 504. These regulations prohibit, among other things, DHS and CBP from: 
3  affording a qualified individual with a disability an opportunity to participate in or 
4  benefit from a benefit or service “that is not equal to that afforded to others;” 
5  providing a qualified individual with a disability with a benefit or service “that is not 
6  as effective in affording equal opportunity to obtain the same result as that provided 
7  to others”; or utilizing criteria or methods of administration the purpose or effect of 
8  which would subject qualified individuals with disabilities to discrimination or defeat 
9  or substantially impair accomplishment of the objectives of a program or activity.” 6 
10  C.F.R. § 15.30. 
11  254.  Section 240 proceedings, and determinations by DHS/CBP as to who 
12  will be returned to Mexico pending those proceedings, constitute a program, activity 
13  or benefit of the federal government. 
14  255.  Each of the Accardi/Section 504 class representatives is a qualified 
15  person with a disability for purposes of Section 504. 
16  256.  Defendants  have  violated  Section  504  by  returning  people  with 
17  disabilities  to  Mexico  pending  or  after  the  conclusion  of  their  Section  240 
18  proceedings, whether or not properly initiated, because doing so: (i) denies people 
19  with disabilities meaningful access to those proceedings; (ii) does not afford them 
20  with an opportunity to participate in Section 240 proceedings that is equal to that 
21  afforded others; (iii) does not provide them with an opportunity to achieve the same 
22  result as others; and (iv) utilizes criteria or methods of administration the purpose or 
23  effect of which subject qualified individuals with disabilities to discrimination and, 
24  thus, defeat or substantially impair accomplishment of the objectives of Section 240 
25  proceedings.  
26  257.  Defendants’  actions  are  also  contrary  to  Defendants’  own 
27  Physical/Mental Health Exclusion policy.  
28  258.  As a result of Defendants’ actions as described herein, members of the 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
52 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  Section 504 class have been, and in the absence of judicial relief will continue to be, 
2  injured. 
3  259.  Putting in place mechanisms to ensure that Defendants follows their 
4  own Physical/Mental Health Exclusion policy and admit members of the Section 504 
5  class into the United States who are currently in Mexico pursuant to the MPP, and in 
6  the future to not return Section 504 class members to Mexico, would constitute a 
7  reasonable accommodation, and is otherwise required by Section 504. 
8  260.  Similarly,  exempting  people  with  disabilities  from  the  MPP  and 
9  allowing those currently in Mexico to pursue their Section 240 proceedings from the 
10  United  States  would  constitute  a  reasonable  accommodation,  and  is  otherwise 
11  required by Section 504.  
12  261.  Further,  in  accordance  with  CBP’s  Family  Unit  policy,  admitting 
13  members of the Family Member class, who provide support to Section 504 class 
14  members and allow such class members to meaningfully participate in Section 240 
15  proceedings, is also a reasonable accommodation, and is otherwise required by 
16  Section 504. 
17  COUNT III 
(Violation of Rehabilitation Act on behalf of the Family Member class) 
18 
19  262.  All of the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though 
20  fully set forth herein. 
21  263.  Each member of the Family Member class has an association with a 
22  person  with  a  disability  who  has  suffered  discrimination  in  violation  of  the 
23  Rehabilitation Act, as described above. 
24  264.  As  a  result  of  the  discrimination  suffered  by  their  disabled  family 
25  member, each member of the Family Member class has been injured because, for 
26  example and without limitation, rather than being able to prepare for their own 
27  Section 240 proceedings, they have had to focus on assisting and supporting their 
28  disabled family member and thus have not been able to meaningfully participate in 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
53 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  Section 240 proceedings. 
2  265.  If members of the Section 504 class are allowed to pursue their Section 
3  240 proceedings from the United States pursuant either to the Rehabilitation Act or 
4  in  compliance  with  Defendants’  Physical/Mental  Health  Exclusion  policy,  any 
5  Family Member class member who is forced to remain in Mexico will be unable to 
6  assist and support their disabled family member. Furthermore, a disabled family 
7  member may be essential to the proper development of a family member’s claim, 
8  leaving them unable to fully develop their claim if forced to remain in the MPP.   As 
9  a result, they will continue to suffer mental trauma and will be unable to meaningfully 
10  participate in Section 240 proceedings. 
11  266.  In the absence of judicial relief, this injury to Family Member class 
12  members is ongoing and will continue. 
13  V.  APPLICATION FOR TEMPORARY RESTRAINING ORDER 
AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
14 
15  267.  Plaintiffs intend to file an Application for Temporary Restraining Order 
16  and Injunctive Relief and Brief in Support, requesting that the court provide relief 
17  consistent with the claims set forth above. 
18  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
19  Plaintiffs  respectfully  request  that  the  Court  enter  a  judgment  against 
20  Defendants and award the following relief:  
21  1.  Issue a temporary restraining order, pending a hearing on the request for a 
22  preliminary injunction, that provides relief that will be identified in Plaintiffs’ 
23  briefing and will be consistent with the claims set forth above;  
24  2.  Declare that the suit is maintainable as a class action pursuant to Federal Rule 
25  of Civil Procedure 23(a) and 23(b)(2); 
26  3.  Adjudge  and  declare  that  the  acts,  omissions,  policies,  and  practices  of 
27  Defendants, and their agents, employees and officials, described herein, are in 
28  violation of the rights of Plaintiffs and the class members they seek to represent 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
54 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
  

 
1  under the Rehabilitation Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act/Accardi 
2  doctrine; 
3  4.  Preliminarily and permanently enjoin Defendants, their agents, employees, 
4  and officials from subjecting Plaintiffs and the class members they seek to 
5  represent  to  the  illegal  and  unconstitutional  conditions,  acts,  omissions, 
6  policies, and practices set forth above; 
7  5.  Issue  an  injunction  requiring  Defendants,  without  limitation,  to:  stop 
8  subjecting members of the Accardi class to the MPP, and to put in place 
9  mechanisms to ensure that their Physical/Mental Health Exclusion policy is 
10  carried out on the ground; to admit family members of Accardi  class members 
11  pursuant to the Family Unit Policy; put in place practices and policies to 
12  identify  immigrants  with  disabilities,  and  to  assess  those  immigrants  for 
13  accommodations necessary to meaningfully prepare for and participate in 
14  Section  240  proceedings  from  the  United  States;  as  part  of  this 
15  accommodations assessment process, determine whether the immigrant with a 
16  disability and their families should be admitted into the United States to pursue 
17  their Section 240 proceedings, either as an accommodation or in compliance 
18  with Defendants’ Physical/Mental Health Exclusion policy; 
19  6.  Require Defendants to pay Plaintiff’s reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs, 
20  pursuant to 29 U.S.C. § 794(a)(b) and 28 U.S.C. § 2412(d); and 
21  7.  Grant all other relief that is just and proper. 
22 
23 
24 
25 
26 
27 
28 
    
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
55 
DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF

01/14/2021  34   Minute Entry for proceedings held with chambers of Magistrate Judge 
Bernard G. Skomal: Plaintiff's counsel contacted Judge Skomal's chambers 
regarding the filing of a motion for expedited discovery on January 14, 
2021. Before any briefing may be filed, the parties must meet and confer. 
If the parties can agree on a proposal, they may file a joint motion with 
their proposal. If they do not agree after meeting and conferring, they may 
file a joint statement setting forth each parties' position on the issue. The 
parties must meet and confer by January 27, 2021 and file either a joint 
motion or a joint statement by February 8, 2021. It must include the parties' 
proposed date to file their Rule 26(f) report and proposed deadlines for 
completion of fact and expert discovery. Additionally, if either party seeks 
discovery related to any particular topics on an expedited basis the scope of 
that discovery should be specifically identified. If a joint statement is filed, 
it is limited to five pages each with any exhibits summarized or quoted 
within the briefing. Because joint statements must include not only each 
parties' position, but a parties' response to the opposing party, the parties 
must exchange their briefing in advance of the deadline to submit a joint 
statement to allow each party to respond to the other's arguments.(no 
document attached) (rxa) (Entered: 01/15/2021)
